Result.Title: Symbolic Model Checking without BDDs

Result.Abstract: The temporal logic model checking algorithm devel- oped by Clarke, Emerson, and Sistla (9) is modified to represent a state graph using Binary decision diagrams (BDD's) (4). Result.Abstract: We present a new methodology for automatic verification of C programs against finite state machine specifications. Our approach is compositional, naturally enabling us to decompose the verification of large software system into subproblems of manageable complexity. The decomposition reflects the modularity in the software design. We use weak simulation as the notion of conformance between the program and its specification.
Result.Title: Modular verification of software components in C

Result.Title: NuSMV 2: An OpenSource Tool for Symbolic Model Checking

Result.Title: Compositional Model Checking

Result.Title: NUSMV: A New Symbolic Model Verifier

Result.Title: Bounded Model Checking Using Satisfiability Solving

Result.Title: Counterexample-guided abstraction refinement for symbolic model checking

Result.Abstract: In practice, finite state concurrent systems often exhibit considerable symmetry. We investigate techniques for reducing the complexity of temporal logic model checking in the presence of symmetry. Result.Title: Exploiting Symmetry In Temporal Logic Model Checking

Result.Title: Bounded model checking

Result.Abstract: Theorem proving and model checking are powerful tools that can verify the logical correctness of today's ICs or find their hidden bugs. Today, the first computer-aided verification tools are becoming commercially available. They are based on methods that in many cases can reduce the complexity of verification (without sacrificing guaranteed correctness) to such a degree that it becomes computationally feasible.
Result.Title: Computer-aided verification

Result.Title: Another Look at LTL Model Checking

Result.Abstract: This paper describes a new symbolic model checker, called NUSMV, developed as part of a joint project between CMU and IRST. Result.Title: Verification of the Futurebus+ Cache Coherence Protocol

Result.Title: Automated Abstraction Refinement for Model Checking Large State Spaces Using SAT Based Conflict Analysis

Result.Abstract: Symbolic model checking is a powerful formal specification and verification method that has been applied successfully in several industrial designs. Using symbolic model checking techniques it is possible to verify industrial-size finite state systems. State spaces with up to 1030 states can be exhaustively searched in minutes. Models with more than 10120 states have been verified using special techniques.
Result.Title: Symbolic Model Checking

Result.Title: Behavioral consistency of C and verilog programs using bounded model checking

Result.Abstract: We investigate the expressive power of linear-time and branching-time temporal logics as fragments of the logic CTL*. We give a simple characterization of those CTL* formulas that can be expressed in linear-time logic. We also give a simple method for showing that certain CTL* formulas cannot be expressed in the branching-time logic CTL. Both results are illustrated with examples.
Result.Title: Expressibility results for linear-time and branching-time logics

Result.Title: A parallel algorithm for constructing binary decision diagrams

Conference.FullName: Verification, Model Checking and Abstract Interpretation

Result.Abstract: Many aspects of computer systems are naturally modeled as param- eterized systems which renders their automatic verication difcult. In well- known examples such as cache coherence protocols and mutual exclusion proto- cols, the unbounded parameter is the number of concurrent processes which run the same distributed algorithm. In this paper, we introduce environment abstrac- tion as a tool for the
Result.Title: Environment Abstraction for Parameterized Verification
